markdownRemark.excerpt: This is the third post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In this post, we will introduce group actions, which give rise to the Cayley’s Theorem…
markdownRemark.html:
This is the third post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In this post, we will introduce group actions, which give rise to the Cayley’s Theorem and the class equation.

  • Definitions and the Cayley’s Theorem
  • Orbits, Isotropy Subgroups and centralizers
  • The Class Equation
  • References

Definitions and the Cayley’s Theorem

Definition 3.1 Group Action

  • Let GGG be a group and XXX be a set. Then an action of GGG on XXX is a function F:G×X→XF: G \times X \to XF:G×X→X, with F(g,x)=g⋅xF(g,x)=g \cdot xF(g,x)=g⋅x, such that
  1. g1⋅(g2⋅x)=(g1g2)⋅x∀g1,g2∈Gg_1 \cdot (g_2 \cdot x)=(g_{1}g_{2}) \cdot x \forall g_1, g_2 \in Gg1​⋅(g2​⋅x)=(g1​g2​)⋅x∀g1​,g2​∈G, x∈Xx \in Xx∈X
  2. e⋅x=x∀x∈Xe \cdot x=x \forall x \in Xe⋅x=x∀x∈X

Definition 3.2 GGG-set

  • With action FFF defined as above, we say that XXX is a GGG-set

Definition 3.3 GGG-subset

  • If XXX is a GGG-set, then a GGG-subset YYY of XXX is a subset Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X such that for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G and y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y, g⋅y∈Yg \cdot y \in Yg⋅y∈Y. A GGG-subset is a GGG-set.

Example 3.4

  • The trivial action: g⋅x=xg \cdot x=xg⋅x=x for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G and x∈Xx \in Xx∈X
  • SnS_nSn​ acts on {1,…,n}\{1,\dots ,n\}{1,…,n} via σ⋅k=σ(k)\sigma \cdot k= \sigma (k)σ⋅k=σ(k)

Proposition 3.5

  • If XXX is a GGG-set and f:G′→Gf:G' \rightarrow Gf:G′→G is a homomorphism, then XXX becomes a G′G'G′-set via g′⋅x=f(g′)⋅xg'\cdot x = f(g') \cdot xg′⋅x=f(g′)⋅x. The proof is trivial using homomorphism. In addition, if H≤GH \leq GH≤G, then a GGG-set is also an HHH-set.

Theorem 3.6 Cayley’s Theorem

  • Let GGG be a finite group. Then there exists an n∈Nn\in Nn∈N such that GGG is isomorphic to a subgroup of SnS_nSn​.

  • ProofProofProof. Let GGG be a finite group, where G={g1,…,gn}G=\{g_{1},\dots ,g_{n}\}G={g1​,…,gn​} and ∣G∣=n|G|=n∣G∣=n. Construct an injective homomorphism f:G→SGf:G \rightarrow S_Gf:G→SG​, let H=Im(f)H=Im(f)H=Im(f), then there’s a corresponding homomorphism from GGG to HHH. Define f:G→Hf:G \rightarrow Hf:G→H, then fff remains injective and is surjective by definition, hence fff is an isomorphism. Define an isomorphism h:SG→Snh:S_{G} \rightarrow S_{n}h:SG​→Sn​, then we have an isomorphism h∘fh\circ fh∘f from GGG to a subgroup of SnS_{n}Sn​. It remains to find an injective homomorphism fff.

Define f:G→SGf:G\rightarrow S_{G}f:G→SG​ by f(g)=lgf(g)=l_{g}f(g)=lg​, where lg(x)=gxl_{g}(x)=gxlg​(x)=gx. Since left multiplication is clearly bijective for every g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, we have lg∈SGl_{g}\in S_{G}lg​∈SG​. Then we can show fff is an injective homomorphism directly.

Using Proposition 3.5, we have a generalization of Cayley’s theorem. For the action of GGG on itself by left multiplication, we define a bijection lg:G→Gl_{g}: G\rightarrow Glg​:G→G where lg(x)=gxl_{g}(x)=gxlg​(x)=gx. For some GGG-set XXX, we have lg:G→Gl_{g}: G\rightarrow Glg​:G→G where lg(x)=gxl_{g}(x)=gxlg​(x)=gx for x∈Xx\in Xx∈X.

Lemma 3.7

  • (i) For all g1,g2∈G,lg1∘lg2=lg1g2g_1,g_2\in G,l_{g_1}\circ l_{g_2} =l_{g_1g_2}g1​,g2​∈G,lg1​​∘lg2​​=lg1​g2​​.
  • (ii) l1=IdXl_1 =Id_Xl1​=IdX​.
  • (iii) lg∈SXl_g\in S_Xlg​∈SX​ forall g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, and the inverse of lgl_glg​ is lg−1l_{g^{−1}}lg−1​.

Corollary 3.8

  • If XXX is a GGG-set, then the function f:G→SXf:G \rightarrow S_Xf:G→SX​ defined by

f(g)=lgf(g)=l_gf(g)=lg​ is a homomorphism from GGG to SXS_XSX​. This follows directly from 3.7.

Definition 3.9 G-isomorphism

If X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​ are GGG-sets, an isomorphism fff from X1X_1X1​ to X2X_2X2​ of GGG-sets, or briefly a GGG-isomorphism is a bijection f:X1→X2f:X_1 \rightarrow X_2f:X1​→X2​ such that f(g⋅x)=g⋅f(x)f(g\cdot x)=g\cdot f(x)f(g⋅x)=g⋅f(x) for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G and x∈Xx\in Xx∈X.

Orbits, Isotropy Subgroups and centralizers

Definition 3.10 Orbits

  • If XXX is a GGG-set and x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the orbit of XXX under GGG is the set G⋅x={g⋅x,g∈G}G \cdot x=\{g \cdot x, g \in G\}G⋅x={g⋅x,g∈G}. We have G⋅x⊆XG \cdot x \subseteq XG⋅x⊆X. Note that G⋅xG\cdot xG⋅x is the smallest GGG-subset of XXX containing xxx.

Proposition 3.11

Let GGG act on a set XXX, and define x∼Gyx\sim_{G} yx∼G​y iff there exists a g∈Gg\in Gg∈G such that g⋅x=yg\cdot x=yg⋅x=y. Then ∼G\sim_G∼G​ is an equivalence relation, and the equivalence class containing xxx is the orbit G⋅xG\cdot xG⋅x. Hence two orbits of GGG are either disjoint or identical.

Definition 3.12 Transitive Action

  • If XXX is a GGG-set and if G⋅x=XG \cdot x=XG⋅x=X for one hence all x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, we say that GG Gacts transitively on XXX.

Definition 3.13 Conjugacy Class

  • The group GGG acts on itself by conjugation. The orbit of x∈Gx \in Gx∈G is the conjugacy class of xxx, the subset C(x) of G consisting of all elements conjugate to x. C(x)={gxg−1:g∈G}C(x)=\{gxg^{-1}:g\in G\}C(x)={gxg−1:g∈G}. Note that the conjugation action is never transitive for non-trivial GGG.

Definition 3.14 Isotropy Subgroup

  • If XXX is a GGG-set and x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the isotropy subgroup GxG_xGx​ is

the set {g∈G,g⋅x=x}\{g \in G, g \cdot x=x\}{g∈G,g⋅x=x}. Clearly Gx≤GG_x \leq GGx​≤G.

Definition 3.15 Fixed Set

For GGG-set XXX, XG={x∈X:g⋅x=x∀g∈G}X^G=\{x\in X: g\cdot x=x \forall g\in G\}XG={x∈X:g⋅x=x∀g∈G}. It is the largest GGG-subset of XXX for which the G_action is trivial.

Proposition 3.16

(i) If XXX is a GGG-set, x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, and y=g⋅x∈G⋅xy=g\cdot x\in G\cdot xy=g⋅x∈G⋅x, then Gy=gGxg−1G_y=gG_{x}g^{-1}Gy​=gGx​g−1. (ii) If XXX is a GGG-set and x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, then there is an isomorphism of GGG-sets from G⋅xG\cdot xG⋅x to G/GxG/G_xG/Gx​. If GGG acts transitively on XXX, then XXX is G-isomorphic to G/GxG/G_xG/Gx​.

ProofProofProof. (i) is obvious. For (ii) define F:G/Gx→G⋅xF:G/G_x \rightarrow G\cdot xF:G/Gx​→G⋅x where F(gGx)=g⋅xF(gG_x)=g\cdot xF(gGx​)=g⋅x. Then it is easy to check isomorphism.

Corollary 3.16

∣G∣=∣Gx∣⋅∣G⋅x∣|G|=|G_x|\cdot |G\cdot x|∣G∣=∣Gx​∣⋅∣G⋅x∣

Definition 3.17 Center and Centralizer

The center of of a group is given by Z(G)={x∈G:gx=xg∀g∈G}Z(G)=\{x\in G:gx=xg \forall g\in G\}Z(G)={x∈G:gx=xg∀g∈G}. The centralizer of a element x∈Gx\in Gx∈G is given by ZG(x)={g∈G:gx=xg}Z_G(x)=\{g\in G: gx=xg\}ZG​(x)={g∈G:gx=xg}.

Example 3.18

If GGG acts on itself by conjugation, then the fixed set GGG^GGG is the center Z(G)Z(G)Z(G), the orbit of x∈Gx \in Gx∈G is the conjugacy class C(x), and the isotropy group of x is the centralizer of x. ZG(x)={g∈G:gxg−1=x}={g∈G:gx=xg}Z_G(x)=\{g\in G:gxg^{−1}=x\}=\{g\in G:gx=xg\}ZG​(x)={g∈G:gxg−1=x}={g∈G:gx=xg}.

The Class Equation

Definition 3.19

Following from example 3.18, let GGG be a finite group that acts on itself by conjugation, then the fixed set GGG^GGG is the center Z(G)Z(G)Z(G), and the orbits G⋅xiG\cdot x_iG⋅xi​ are conjugacy classes C(xi)={gxig−1:g∈G}C(x_i)=\{gx_{i}g^{-1}:g\in G\}C(xi​)={gxi​g−1:g∈G}. Hence we have the class equation ∣G∣=∣Z(G)∣+∑i∣C(xi)∣|G|=|Z(G)|+\sum_{i} |C(x_i)|∣G∣=∣Z(G)∣+∑i​∣C(xi​)∣.

References

[1] Siegel, Kyler. MATH GU4041 Introduction to Modern Algebra I. Department of Mathematics, Columbia University. 2019.

[2] Dummit, David and Foote, Richard. Abstract Algebra. Third Edition. John Wiley and Sons, Inc. 2004.

frontmatter.title: Abstract Algebra 03 - Group Actions
frontmatter.description: This is the third post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In this post, we will introduce group actions, which give rise to the Cayley's Theorem and the class equation.
